fullProgramDescription: The Physics B.S. program at UCLA is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles of physics, including mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, and quantum mechanics. The program includes a rigorous curriculum of theoretical and experimental courses, as well as opportunities for research and hands-on learning. Students are prepared for careers in research, industry, and education, as well as graduate study in physics and related fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Physics B.S. program at UCLA provides a comprehensive education in physics, preparing students for careers in research, industry, and education, as well as graduate study.
classHighlights: The introductory physics sequence, including Physics 1A, 1B, and 1C, or Physics 5A, 5B, and 5C, provides a foundation in classical mechanics, electromagnetism, and thermodynamics.
The intermediate physics sequence, including Physics 105A, 105B, and 115A, covers topics such as mathematical methods, classical mechanics, and electromagnetism.
Upper-division courses, including Physics 115B, 115C, 131, 132, and 133, provide advanced training in areas such as quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, and computational physics.
Laboratory courses, including Physics 4AL, 4BL, and 105CL, provide hands-on experience with experimental techniques and data analysis.
Electives, such as Physics 110A, 110B, and 118, allow students to explore specialized topics and deepen their understanding of physics.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles of physics, including mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, and quantum mechanics.
Apply mathematical and computational techniques to solve physics problems.
Design and conduct experiments to test hypotheses and measure physical phenomena.
Analyze and interpret data to draw conclusions and make predictions.
Communicate complex physics concepts effectively in written and oral form.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a minimum of 180 quarter units, including major requirements, general education, and electives. Research opportunities are available for students to work with faculty members on research projects.
